author: @Chris-Christopher-

comment:
@coolunusual  I understand your point about Google providing multiple sources and cross-referencing information. However, GPT and similar technologies have distinct advantages over basic search engines, which I believe is important for you to consider.

Firstly, GPT-based systems can provide more concise and coherent responses to queries, as they are designed to understand the context and generate human-like responses. This can save time and effort compared to sifting through multiple sources on a search engine. 

Secondly, these technologies are continuously improving and learning from new data, making their responses more accurate and relevant over time. While search engines do update their algorithms, they often rely on users to discern the reliability of the information presented.

It's essential to recognize that no tool is perfect, and both GPT and search engines have their limitations. However, dismissing GPT-based technologies as inherently flawed or refusing to acknowledge their potential benefits will only hinder your ability to adapt and make use of these tools effectively in the future. 

Being intentionally obtuse and dismissive about such technologies may result in missed opportunities to learn and grow. Instead, I encourage you to approach these technologies with an open mind and a willingness to learn how to use them correctly, as they can offer valuable insights and streamline information access if used appropriately.

--teehee
author: @Chris-Christopher-

Aside from the advantage of speed and a select few cases i think I'll be better off finding what i need myself.

author: @oowaz

comment:
​ @robertspies4695  "How do you decide to trust the information the AI gives you?" 
This is one of the biggest challenges with AI right now. Noam Chomsky said recently that while AI can "think", it can't *introspect*. It needs some kind of guidance, error correction, error checking. 

...and thus it goes down the line until we get to, "what is truth?" What is real? What is fact? What is the hierarchy of "truth" from different levels of sources?
author: @joegibes
@Chris-Christopher-

comment: ​​​ @Chris-Christopher-  The difference between ChatGPT and Google is like the difference between asking a professor in a college a question and taking everything he says at face value even though he could be fucking with you, or going to the library and searching for the answer yourself. The professor is really smart and knows what he's talking about, but he's still only giving you one answer and his understanding of it. Google is a library giving you every article, web page and book that has ever been written on any subject. Clearly they're not the same.
author: @jakehiller6444

comment: @jakehiller6444  I don't think I said they were the same. In fact I've mentioned using other sources in conjunction to GPT. The point is that ChatGPT gives you something that google or just going through books cannot. It gives you responses in the context of what you're doing. At least it does if you're using it in a way to get those results. It doesn't replace traditional sources. It's just another tool (an awesome tool) that is used in addition to those. We also keep in mind that we're still pretty early in the development of this stuff. It's very useful as it is now when used correctly. I can only imagine how much more useful it will be in the future.

author: @mihirsrivastava1113

comment:
A large language model like chat gpt is nothing more than a text based version of Alexa which is a verbal natural language interface.    By itself chatgpt only knows how to have a conversation in a given language but not using spoken language.  However, being that it has a large volume of data it has been trained on, there is also the idea that a useful side effect of such a model is that there is some kind of knowledge embedded in it by default.   But that embedded knowledge is not perfect knowledge or genius level knowledge of any specific domain in a rigorous sense and cannot be sold as such.  However, a lot of discussion about these side effects implies that it is somehow more than it is because unfortunately those side effects are not robust in and of themselves to be replacements for applications dedicated to specific tasks.  It is just a natural language interface that can be used to augment existing features and applications with natural language capability and functionality.    For example,  chat gpt in bing is not replacing search functionality, but bringing a natural language interface to search.   As time goes on the functionality will evolve and third parties will come up with more use cases for it but by itself it can only do so much.

Also, the biggest problem with these discussions that I have is that historically the development of computer science as a discipline has always been to augment human intellect and not replace it.  This idea that these algorithms and systems are being designed to be synthetic humans aka AGI is totally false.  Of course computers can calculate things faster than the human brain, but that doesn't make it human. At the end of the day these are tools for humans to use in analyzing, organizing and processing information.

comment:
@brightwithspirit  you have to use it for stuff that is important to you. Not just use it to make silly stories, create hilarious insults to use against your friends, or try to use to make political points. I've been using it a lot to help further my understanding of technical nerd stuff that I like to do. It's awesome for stuff like that because you can explain to it what you're doing and then ask questions and it will answer them in a way that has the context of what you're doing. Unlike searching google in which you might find something related, but then you have to figure how and if you can map that to your specific needs.

I also recently used it to learn how pool pump systems work because I had to figure one out. I used it in conjunction with some other resources, but I was able to use that clarify and dig into concepts that I didn't fully grasp. I would ask questions if I understood something correctly too, and it would give a reasonable response. Sure, maybe it could give some false information, but that  is why we don't just completely give in and have it guide us completely. It's a tool. A very useful tool.
